Maria Miller is the minister for women and equalities. I thought I'd mention that because, from her interview with the Telegraph published on Tuesday, you might think she was the minister for something else entirely. Minister for specious claims and lack of evidence, maybe. Minister for faux-concern and anti-choice.

One of the things that attracted attention when Miller took up her new appointment was her record on abortion: in 2008, she voted to reduce the legal limit on abortion from 24 weeks to 20. Asked by Cathy Newman if she'd do the same again, Miller replied: "Absolutely." So the minister charged with representing women's rights in parliament has committed herself to restricting women's control over their own fertility. Let's have a sour little cheer for a woman's right to choose to do whatever she likes once in power, regardless of what might be best for the rest of the gender she supposedly has the portfolio for.

This focus on late-term abortion is a misleading way to steer public sentiment against abortion, and when Miller uses it, she's following a path that's been well established by deceitful media practices. But Miller isn't some doctrinaire opponent of abortion. No, Miller is a self-described "very modern feminist" who claims to be "driven by that very practical impact that late-term abortion has on women … What we are trying to do here is not to put obstacles in people's way but to reflect the way medical science has moved on."

How has medical science moved on, then? The Epicure study conducts ongoing research into the care of very premature babies – those born before 27 weeks' gestation. That has found a significant improvement in survival rates at 24 and 25 weeks, but not for those born at 22 or 23 weeks. A baby born at 22 weeks' gestation has a 1% chance of survival from the onset of labour. That can't be the medical science that's persuaded Miller there should be a 20-week limit, then.

She says she's worried about the effects on women. Let's have a look at the systematic review of induced abortion and women's mental health, from the Academy of Medical Royal Colleges. That found that "the rates of mental health problems for women with an unwanted pregnancy are the same, whether they have an abortion or give birth", which again doesn't seem to cover Miller's "very practical impact … on women" (unless by "very practical" she means "completely invisible").

Abortions at over 20 weeks' gestation accounted for 1.4% of all terminations in 2010. Miller has won headlines with a position that has no evidence to support it, and that would have a negligible effect on abortion rates overall if adopted in law. Negligible, that is, except for the harm it would cause to the women who need procedures at this stage – women who may be ending a much-wanted pregnancy because their circumstances have drastically changed, women who may have physical or psychological reasons for failing to acknowledge their pregnancy soon, women who desperately need the safety net of safe, legal, late abortion.

For those women, restricting abortion to 20 weeks would be disastrous. But for anti-abortion campaigners, a simplistic and dishonest focus on the fringe cases is useful, because they can identify all abortion with the sentimental image of the obviously pregnant woman. Look at the picture used to illustrate the Telegraph's interview with Miller: the torso of a woman who looks eight months pregnant if she's a day, the bump protectively cradled by her arms. It's a theme repeated again and again, by the Telegraph, the Mail, the Metro and so many outlets that there's a Tumblr to compile them all: the inevitable pregobelly.

If newspapers and websites wanted to give an honest picture of abortion, 90% of stories would be illustrated with pictures of completely flat stomachs. The other 10% would have a picture of a woman's midriff that's just big enough to make you wonder if she's pregnant, but then decide on balance that she might just be getting a bit thick round the middle and it would be rude to mention it.

If the media wanted to be really truthful, they could expand the crop to show her face, which would carry an expression of dread or distress at the prospect of maternity. But that would mean treating women as individuals, with individual circumstances, capable of making their own choices in their own best interests. When Miller suggests that she's trying to protect women from the consequences of abortion, what the minister for women and equalities is really saying is that she doesn't trust women.

My friend and colleague of 20 years, Jeremy Pope, who has died aged 73, was one of the pioneers in what is now a global movement to curb corruption and improve integrity in government.

Jeremy was born in Wellington, New Zealand, and educated at the Anglican St Peter's Cambridge preparatory school and at Wanganui Collegiate school. He was very involved in all aspects of school life, including cricket and drama, and music, in which he excelled. When moving on to Victoria University, Wellington, it was a toss-up whether he would study music or law. Law won.

In 1963 he married Diana Miller (who had said she would marry him only if and when he completed his degree, which he duly did). They were an incredibly close couple, role models for many who knew them. In the 1970s they co-authored a bestselling travel guide to New Zealand which remained continuously in print for more than 20 years.

Jeremy's father, who worked for the Chicago Tribune and New York Times, reporting on the Chinese revolution and the Korean and Vietnam wars, triggered his interest in global affairs. As an editor of the New Zealand Law Journal in the 1970s, Jeremy denounced New Zealand's sporting contacts with South Africa. He was responsible for the introduction of the country's duty solicitor scheme.

In 1976 he was appointed assistant director of the legal and constitutional affairs division of the Commonwealth secretariat in London, and in 1980 became director of the division. During his time in London he became the only non-African member of Sanroc, the South African Non-Racial Olympic Committee, which led campaigns to isolate South Africa in protest against apartheid on the sports field.

In 1993, with six others, he co-founded Transparency International (TI), an anti-corruption organisation based in Berlin. From 1993 to 1997, he was its first managing director; he stepped down to head a research and development unit in London from 1997 to 2003. At TI, he was the catalyst for the first open discussions on corruption and governance involving civil society in numerous countries, often in environments of official hostility, for instance in parts of Africa, the Middle East and the former Soviet Union. He inspired hundreds of activists to take up this struggle. He was appointed an anti-corruption adviser to the World Bank president in 1995.

In 2003 Jeremy parted ways with TI, and co-founded Tiri, an organisation dedicated to taking the anti-corruption movement in a new direction. We started Tiri without any funding, so we worked from Jeremy and Diana's kitchen for the first two years. This suited Jeremy, who could work in his shorts and T-shirt. In the last four years, after he returned to Wellington, he served on New Zealand's Human Rights Commission, where he was noted for his courage, good humour and gentle wisdom.

Jeremy is survived by Diana and their children, Adam, Jemima and Samuel, and grandchildren, Jessica and Miki.

For a few hours on Wednesday, Manchester seemed to come to a standstill to pay tribute to a 23-year-old police officer who was killed along with her colleague as they attended an apparently routine callout last month.

Deansgate, one of the city's main thoroughfares, was lined with thousands of officers in dress uniform and members of the public forming a black line, several rows deep, as the cortege made its way to Manchester Cathedral, where the funeral service for Nicola Hughes was held.

The crowds outside broke into spontaneous applause as the coffin, shrouded in black cloth, was carried inside to the sound of Pie Jesu. Hughes's parents, Susan and Bryn, and her younger brother, Sam, followed the coffin into the cathedral. The force's flag flew at half-mast overhead. In a building opposite, people stood by red, white and blue flowers spelling out RIP.

A large framed portrait of a smiling Hughes was placed next to her coffin, which was topped with white flowers and her police cap and gloves. The Greater Manchester police chaplain, the Rev Charles Nevin, said: "While we cannot change what has been, we cannot turn back the clock but we can show by our presence in this cathedral, and in the streets, homes and offices of this land, that we stand beside you."

Among the dignitaries at the service were senior police officers and chief constables from all the UK's police forces, as well as civic leaders and Sir Bobby Charlton.

Greater Manchester's chief constable, Sir Peter Fahy, said it was abhorrent that Hughes had met her death in such a way, "but the best tribute we can make to her memory is that we continue to uphold the standards and the style of policing she demonstrated so well and ensure that might does not conquer over justice".

Hughes was 21 when she joined the force in August 2009, and had impressed the selection panel with her readiness for the job. "Despite her young years, she was incredibly mature," Fahy said.

She was initially a neighbourhood officer, then a response officer on C relief at Tameside. She set high standards for herself and impressed everyone with her dedication and cheerfulness, Fahy said. "She had huge amounts of energy and initiative."

He said Hughes proved herself to be highly capable in situations of disorder, brave when searching apparently unoccupied premises and going into the unknown, and on the other hand compassionate towards victims of crime. He recounted one occasion when she stopped her police van to rescue a mouse being fought over by two cats and release it into a nearby field.

Fahy said she had known full well the risk the job entailed, as her father was a prison officer. He said Hughes and her colleague Fiona Bone had many of the qualities of young police officers and young people who did not have the prejudices and hangups of his generation, and who "take people as they are, whatever their background".

"Nicola signed up to the police service knowing that she would put herself in danger. She understood that the unarmed status of British policing is not some tactical option or us holding on to an historic tradition now out of date. She understood it is central to our commitment to the minimum use of force to our relationship with the public and to serving citizens rather than controlling them as some arm of the state," he said.

"It is clear from every conversation we have with them that her family were so proud of Nicola. She was a fighter whether engaged in her favourite sport of karate or fighting for justice for a victim of crime. Nevertheless it is her warm smile and her gentleness that stand out from every picture of her. She will be greatly missed by everyone that knew her. We will never forget her great sacrifice."

Hughes was described as a vibrant young woman who had worked as a waitress at the Bull's Head in Delph and liked keeping fit, looking after her nails and hair, and socialising. She was a green belt in karate and loved singing with headphones on – and though she thought she could sing, her family never dared to tell her otherwise.

Her colleague Sergeant Stephen Miskell said: "Nicola, with only three years' service, was already greatly respected and loved by her colleagues, who would variously describe her as being friendly, full of life, always willing to give a helping hand, as keen as mustard, as brave as they come and the chatterbox who always kept everybody else awake." He said her home-baked chocolate muffins had been a personal favourite.

Shareholders have stepped up their campaign to remove Rupert Murdoch as chairman of News Corporation ahead of the media company's annual meeting this month.

Hermes, a British fund manager that controls £24.8bn assets, joined an action on Wednesday launched by dissident shareholders seeking to oust News Corp's chairman in the wake of the phone-hacking scandal.

Glass Lewis, one of the largest shareholder advisory groups, has also recommended its clients vote for the appointment of an independent chair. This is the second year that major shareholders have rounded on Murdoch and his board.

Hans Hirt, global head of corporate engagement at Hermes, said: "While we acknowledge the recent board changes made by the company, News Corp has still not sufficiently addressed the significant shareholder concerns about its board structure and corporate culture highlighted at last year's annual meeting. The time is right for the company to appoint an independent chair in order to rebuild trust, and ensure that the interests of all investors are more properly represented."

The resolution was co-filed by Christian Brothers Investment Services (CBIS) and members of the Local Authority Pension Fund Forum (LAPFF). It will be voted on at the company's annual meeting in Los Angeles on 16 October.

A similar vote last year failed to pass. Murdoch and his family own about 12% of the media giant but control 40% of the vote because of News Corp's dual class share structure. Last year, the majority of independent voters voted against much of News Corp's board including Murdoch's sons Lachlan and James.

This year's meeting comes amid rumours that News Corp is considering appointing James Murdoch to head Fox Networks, the division that runs the firm's flagship Fox channel. Such a move would come in a year that has seen James Murdoch criticised for his handling of the hacking revelations and resign as chairman of both News International, the company's British newspaper division, and BSkyB, the British satellite broadcaster that it controls.

Julie Tanner, director of socially responsible investing at CBIS, called the speculation a "slap in the face for shareholders, not to mention victims of the hacking scandal".

Do we, as opposed to authors, publishers and TV celebrities, need any more cookbooks? Are there any really new recipes out there?

Ninety-nine per cent of cookbooks and accompanying TV programmes are not about cooks at all. They are about chefs. A new word should be used to describe them: chefbooks. A cook is someone who, with no training, has to feed themselves and a family three times a day, often on a tight budget. There are millions of people in this country doing just that, with no help from the famous chefs. It's not about new recipes; it's about teaching a whole generation economy and nutrition.

Linda Williamson, Sheffield

I have something like 30 spices in my kitchen, half a dozen meats in my freezer, and a dozen veg in my fridge. Take into account the different ways these could be combined, and there must be trillions of combinations. Most would be inedible, but that still leaves enough recipes for billions of cookbooks.

buserian

It isn't only cookery books that are in surplus. When I reviewed books for East London Organic Gardeners Newsletter I was amazed to see the number of books about herbs. It seemed every publisher had to produce at least one, but this didn't lead to any great originality. Although I am all in favour of recycling, I had to object when many lifted from other books and repeated hoary old myths without any effort to check for the truth.

If we were to build a massive dam across the Strait of Gibraltar, would the Mediterranean dry up, or flood?

The Mediterranean is more salty than the Atlantic. From this we can infer that it loses more water to evaporation than it gains from rainfall and river discharge. So one would expect that it would shrink if it was cut off from the Atlantic. However, as it shrank, it's surface area would be reduced, and thus the rate of evaporation would decrease. It's possible that it might then reach an equilibrium at a size smaller than present where the evaporation was equal to the rainfall and river flow.

In recent years we've seen the Aral Sea shrink when much of the river flow into that sea was diverted for agriculture. We could expect that the use of the Nile in a similar way would have had an impact on the size of a Mediterranean sea cut off from the Atlantic.

ThermoStat

A complaint to the European Commission that the supreme court's decision in Jivraj v Hashwani breaches European laws against discrimination may have major implications for equality and religious freedom.

In 1981, two businessmen from the Ismaili Muslim community, Hashwani and Jivraj signed a contract relating to a joint business venture and included a clause referring disputes to arbitrators who were required to be members of the Ismaili community. Now, 30 years later, this arbitration clause has been considered at every level of the English court system, anda referral to the European court of justice (ECJ) has been requested.

Arbitration has a long history and today is more popular than ever. From multinational corporations to sole traders, businesses arbitrate so that they can choose who will decide their disputes, and avoid the time and cost of court proceedings.

After a lengthy dispute between Hashwani and Jivraj about tax issues, the Ismaili arbitrator adjudicating it resigned. Hashwani failed to find a qualified Ismaili replacement and appointed retired judge Sir Anthony Coleman as arbitrator. Jivraj objected on the basis that Coleman is not a member of the Ismaili community and his appointment breached the arbitration clause. Hashwani responded that the clause is unenforceable under European legislation and the Equality Act 2010 because it unfairly discriminates against non-Ismaili arbitrators.

In 2011, the supreme court held, in favour of Jivraj, that arbitrators are not protected by equality legislation, and, even if they are, the requirement for an arbitrator from the Ismaili community was a "genuine occupational requirement". Following the supreme court's decision, a new arbitrator from the Ismaili community was appointed. However, when this arbitrator resignedHashwani asked the European Commission to refer the case to ECJ.

An ECJ decision could be far reaching. The "genuine occupational requirement" depends on whether it is genuinely necessary for the arbitrator to be from the Ismaili community to decide the dispute. The supreme court thought it was, but Hashwani says the issues in dispute simply require a suitably qualified lawyer, of any religion, and that his problems finding an arbitrator from the Ismaili community reinforce this. His lawyer, Sarosh Zaiwalla, says: "This is a commercial dispute which in reality only required an experienced lawyer – there was no question of religion. Hashwani was forced to seek to appoint a non-Ismaili arbitrator because, after 20 years of legal proceedings, that was the only way he could get justice".

The supreme court commented that a decision by a religious organisation only to employ a lawyer of its own religion was unlikely to be permitted under the Equality Act. It is only a short further step to say that discrimination by private parties appointing arbitrators should not be permitted either. A decision by the ECJ to this effect would be the final nail in the coffin for religious arbitration.

In finding that arbitrators are not protected by equality legislation the supreme court, in the second limb of its decision, distinguished between employment and self-employment and restricted the extent to which equality legislation protects the self-employed. The ECJ may well disagree. Should arbitrators, or indeed doctors, plumbers or anyone else who is self-employed, be protected from discrimination? Or, to reverse the question, should a person who privately instructs a solicitor, a dentist, or an electrician, have their personal choice subject to the full gamut of equality legislation?

Supporters of the supreme court say that parties should have the freedom to choose their arbitrator taking into account their religious beliefs and that the judgment safeguards the flexibility and neutrality of arbitration. Hashwani, however, argues this is tantamount to an employer saying "no blacks, Christians or gays". Sir Richard Buxton, a retired judge who heard the case in the court of appeal, said the decision is a licence for parties to agree not to appoint "a woman, a Jew, or a homosexual".

The case involves the balancing of two conflicting principles of human rights: equality and the elimination of discrimination on the one hand, versus religious and personal freedom on the other.

It was an idea that first emerged at the end of the heyday of cyber-utopianism: Bitcoin, the virtual and universal currency that could be exchanged for goods and services online, the brainchild of a mysterious pseudonymous cryptographer.

Since its formal launch in 2009, Bitcoin has been adopted by a variety of organisations, including WikiLeaks, the Electronic Frontier Freedom Foundation (albeit briefly) and a number of online traders.

But others, too, saw its unique advantages – including criminals who have allegedly used it for money-laundering. More recently a Bitcoin savings and loan bank came under investigation for being a fraudulent Ponzi scheme.

Now, following these controversies, some of its leading supporters have launched a foundation designed to rehabilitate the reputation of the fledging online "currency".

The Bitcoin Foundation is modelled on the Linux Foundation, the non-profit group that promotes the popular open source operating system. Its purpose is clear: to attempt to restore faith in a system bedevilled by a reputation for fraud and criminality.

The most recent episode saw thieves with a Russian IP address raid Bitfloor – a US online trading floor for the currency, stealing $250,000-worth of Bitcoins.

First proposed by an online cryptographer who styled himself "Satoshi Nakamoto" – a real identity has never been established – it was initially adopted by a small group of cyber-utopians, including Gavin Andresen, a US computer code-writer and one of the figures behind the new foundation.

While individual units of the currency are minted – or "mined" in Bitcoin's terminology – by a complex system, most of those who use Bitcoins purchase them by exchanging them for conventional currency.

However, fraudsters have developed systems for quickly "minting" currency that have undermined it while other criminal enterprises have been quick to see the advantages of the system. In 2011, the US Senate called for Bitcoin to be investigated for its links to tax evasion and money-laundering.

A statement from the foundation last week explained the problems Bitcoin had encountered, and how it would attempt to solve them. It said: "As the Bitcoin economy has evolved, we have all noticed barriers to its widespread adoption – [programmes] that attempt to undermine the network, hackers that threaten wallets, and an undeserved reputation stirred by ignorance and inaccurate reporting.

"There's a lot to love [but] … there are botnet operators, hackers, and Ponzi-scheme runners floating around our space," explained the company's chairman, Peter Vessenes.

He also alluded to the fact that some governments are far from delighted with the prospect of an online alternative to state-issued currencies. "We occasionally hear threatening statements from government representatives that don't seem to understand the law, much less how great Bitcoins are for the world.

… There are legal questions to be answered about Bitcoins, different ones in different jurisdictions."

Perhaps inevitably, given its online context, the currency also fuelled a speculative bubble and subsequent collapse, seeing its value after launch peak at nearly $30 in June 2011 before crashing to $2 late last year.

So given the problems, why would anyone want Bitcoins? One answer was supplied in a recent article on the currency in the Economist that described transactions on a shady website known as Silk Road – a "sort of eBay for drugs hidden in a dark corner of the web" – which saw, according to the magazine's best estimate, Bitcoin transactions to the value of almost $2m (£1.24m) a month.

This statement covers all our significant findings regarding issues covered in the Operations section of the Living Our Values report to date. As we are using a rolling assurance process alongside the rolling publication of sections in the report, we may add additional findings that come to light as we investigate each section. All significant claims made and the data covering energy, carbon, waste recycling and paper sourcing in this section have been assured.

The Guardian has made further progress towards the goal of reporting comprehensive data that reflects the significant environmental impacts of the business. We previously highlighted the lack of data about the impacts of digital publication – an area that many media organisations continue to ignore.

So it is particularly pleasing to see the Sympact project start to bear fruit with the publication of an estimated carbon footprint for the theguardian.com website. This is a difficult area to tackle and the Guardian deserves credit for generating some tangible numbers, albeit estimates at this stage, and for appointing a board-level champion with responsibility for digital sustainability.

Ultimately, the goal should be to understand and quantify digital impacts to at least the same level as the Guardian currently achieves for its paper publications and then to set meaningful improvement targets. There is still a long way to go to get to this point and the Guardian should maintain its drive for digital sustainability, reflecting the direction that the business is taking.

The availability of the Sympact data has allowed the Guardian to widen further the scope of its carbon footprint reporting and this is to be applauded. GNM should now consider presenting its carbon footprint data using the "Scopes" defined by the international GHG Protocol Initiative.

This template has been widely adopted by other reporting organisations and is increasingly being used to frame legislation (for example the draft regulations that will require reporting of GHG emissions by UK quoted companies). This will help clarify the boundaries of the footprint and facilitate comparison, both with previous years' data reported by the Guardian and with data reported by other organisations.

Last year, we commented on the lack of print site waste management data and so it is good to see some reported this year. At present it is not possible to give a comprehensive breakdown by waste category for each site, which would help to improve clarity of reporting for next year.

Collecting data is not an end in itself, but a means of measuring performance. Once again the Guardian is able to demonstrate performance improvements in energy use, water consumption and waste recycling in the areas where there is direct management control. This is a reflection of the continuing efforts of staff at the editorial offices and print sites to implement improvement initiatives day-to-day.

Managing impacts in the supply chain, where there is less direct control, is more difficult and the increase in emissions associated with business travel is an example of this. The efforts of the procurement team to integrate sustainability into purchasing contracts should help to address this issue, building on the Guardian's excellent track record of measuring and improving the sustainability of its paper supplies.

Isn't it interesting how people queue to buy the latest IT gizmo – especially if that gizmo is perceived or promoted to be part of new "best practice" standards. I believe that much damage has been done to social housing operations and budgets over the past decade by organisations including the (now thankfully defunct) Audit Commission and the Chartered Institute of Housing (CIH) promoting dysfunctional IT systems.

I would like to share my thoughts about 'personal digital assistants', or PDAs. The CIH repairs charter recommends IT products such as these as the answer to the challenges of workfoce management. These devices typically cost housing providers more than £200,000 per year.

PDAs are a major part of an organisational problem, not part of a solution. Procurement best practice endorses and sustains the use of these pointless and costly devices. The use of PDAs in the large social housing providers I have worked with has been shown to cause serious financial loss to the client while providing profits for contractors. In one case alone, a housing association faced a loss of £2m a year directly ascribable to the use of PDAs.

The argument in favour of IT claims that PDAs will allow senior management in an organisation to understand in detail what is happening in their repairs and maintenance services. Costs will be under control, and visible to those responsible for managing them.

This is nonsense. In my experience, they do nothing of the sort. The everyday use of these devices in housing associations across the UK goes something like this:

• A responsive repairs request comes in to an organisation's call centre.

• The job is assessed by someone who doesn't understand how all the elements of a building work and given a schedule of rates (SoR) code using repairs fault diagnosis software. An appointment is forced on a tenant, the timing of which meets the needs of the housing provider's "dynamic scheduling software" – not the tenant.

• The job is sent to a tradesperson's PDA, with a time slot for the work based on what the software thinks the problem is – not the analysis of skilled repairs staff.

• Often the work cannot be done in that time slot, because it is more complicated than expected or the member of staff does not have the necessary materials. The worker has to tell the tenant to re-book the job.

• The PDA just keeps filling up with more jobs, despite complications or urgencies encountered at the jobs already attended.

• If there are other repairs that need done at a property, the member of staff is not allowed to complete them – however simple – because it's not registered on the PDA. This means that contractors are paid extra, as they have to return to a property unnecessarily.

• The job is charged to the contractor client on the basis of a meaningless code, and not the actual work that has been carried out.

• The senior leaders' management information system for the housing association repairs service looks great. In reality, it is full of inaccurate nonsense.

Stoke city council has just won a Tenant Participation Advisory Service national award for good customer experience in its repairs service. One of the reasons they won the award was because the council insisted that PDAs were no longer used to carry out this work. You can listen to staff from Stoke council talking openly about the damage to its repairs performance caused specifically by the use of this apparently revolutionary IT. It may make you think differently about how you monitor your own repairs and maintenance staff.

John Little is housing lead practitioner at Vanguard Consulting

The procurement department at GNM was formed in July 2010 to deliver a strategic sourcing approach, and the last financial year was spent developing policies and procedures.

A significant step to embedding sustainable thinking into procurement was the board-approved mandate, of which sustainability is key thread. This requires the majority of our supplier spend to be strategically reviewed by the central procurement team.

By having a centralised department overseeing purchasing, GNM can ensure it generates real value for the business, society and the planet.

Paper procurement for our newspapers and magazines is our single largest third-party spend and highly significant from a sustainability risk perspective. We have in place a comprehensive sustainable paper-sourcing policy, and we work very closely with our suppliers to monitor sustainability performance.

This is achieved through the collection of real-time data that allows GNM to see on a monthly basis how much paper we are buying, the percentages of recycled and virgin fibre being used, certification levels, and also carbon intensities.

For more details on our performance against our paper key performance indicators please visit the paper section.

We are now beginning to pay more attention to the managing and reporting of the sustainability credentials of our key suppliers in the digital field.

This is already proving to be challenging for a number of reasons. One is that it is difficult to get quality information from suppliers about the environmental footprint and social justice aspects of the digital products and services they sell.

Beyond this, we lack in digital what we have in paper purchasing: a single expert who understands the newsprint market inside out. Also, the world of digital is more diverse and complex and therefore harder to understand.
This is a problem shared by most companies, and GNM has been able to make progress thanks to the innovative digital footprint research we have been supporting.

Nevertheless, this difficulty in relating to digital impacts still makes it difficult to fully engage senior managers in discussions, especially during periods of structural change.

Where we need to make improvements is in creating a clear framework and language to allow the organisation to systematically consider risks and opportunities when making decisions.

We also need to clarify the boundaries of our responsibility. Is it the computer hardware makers, the networks, or the consumer who logs on to our website?

If the answer is "all of the above", we need to understand better how to account for these and separate them out in a meaningful way.

Internal training

To increase our knowledge of sustainable procurement in general, a number of workshops were held for staff.

Working with the internal procurement team, the focus was on looking at how sustainable thinking could identify broader and more complex risks and opportunities that may affect costs over the length of the contract.

Examples from a range of organisations was used to show how sustainable procurement provides business resilience through better control, awareness and traceability throughout the value chain.

The Guardian Offers/Revenue team, which sells products ranging from travel to books, have been keen to develop a sustainability policy for their customers and suppliers as part of their commitment to openness and transparency.

Workshops for this department focused on helping them to identify key risks within their supply chain that should be controlled through a sustainability policy and appropriate due diligence. The travel policy is now live.

Tendering and contracts

GNM does not have the budgets or buying power of a large multinational company, so we must use the contracting and post-contracting stage of the process to influence service delivery and sustainability.

We recognise that smaller suppliers can find it difficult to provide relevant information, so we are looking to develop flexibility in the sustainability questions we ask to avoid bidders being put off. The questions are being developed around how our demands for services and products drive emissions, consumption and ethical working practices.

Our tendering templates are flexible, consisting of a core template that is agreed and then modified to fit the needs of the business, the specific risks associated with the purchase and maximising value from the suppliers.

Also, more specific questions have been developed regarding what the supplier will do to help reduce our impacts and meet targets, rather than whether they simply have a CSR policy or not.

Even though GNM is going through a period of radical change, we remain dedicated to developing sustainable supply chains. To help ensure this, the sustainability team advises the procurement department during each tender process.

In the past, the procurement department ensured that sustainability was integrated into purchasing, but we found that a core weakness was that individual departments often did not follow up and ensure that our suppliers met their original commitments.

To ensure this does not continue, we have put specific targets into contracts. In some cases, this means implementing sustainability goals at the outset where perhaps previously they did not exist.

An excellent example of this in action was the 2011 tender for the consolidation of travel services. GNM's sustainability department was involved from the outset, identifying the appropriate sustainability areas for potential suppliers to cover during the tender drafting.

Shortlisted suppliers were asked to demonstrate how they would support GNM in reducing travel emissions as well as costs. The responses were assessed by GNM's environmental and sustainability manager Christopher Hodgson, who also attended the tender interviews.

The winning contractor was asked to:

  • Provide appropriate data to enable GNM to calculate and monitor its full carbon and environmental footprint
  • Provide analysis of this data to understand patterns, identify irregularities and suggest opportunities for improvements
  • Assist the setting and delivering of travel sustainability targets that support and align with GNM sustainability objectives and targets
  • Propose a mechanism for travellers and travel bookers to determine or identify the true cost of travel decision and alternatives
  • Encourage travel bookers to book a sustainable travel option and identify opportunities to reduce travel

Progress on actually delivering on these goals has so far been mixed. While we now have full carbon reporting for our travel, the more innovative elements have not yet been addressed and will require more focus from GNM.

In the last financial year, effort was put into minimising waste and reducing our carbon footprint. This year, this section of the report focuses on our head office in King's Cross, London. However, carbon emissions include both our Manchester office and our newly opened New York Office.

Carbon Footprint

Office-based carbon emissions (including our data centre) fell by 7% or 270tCO2e in the last financial year, despite the fact that we opened a new office in New York. Our London headquarters at King's Place saw both gas and electricity consumption fall, resulting in emissions per member of staff falling by 9% to 2.3tCO2e.

Other improvements included fitting stand-alone air-conditioning units for our archive centre so that the main building chillers do not run out of office hours. The cost of the installation will be recouped in a matter of months through available energy savings.

Waste Footprint

A campaign called Love Your Waste was launched last year across Guardian News & Media, resulting in an increase in recycling rates, including composting, from 66% to 78%. All waste is managed according to current legislation, and, even though we do recycle WEEE (ie computers, mobiles), batteries, toner cartridges and CDs, this data was not available for inclusion in the waste figures.

Beyond improving signage and bins, we wanted to impress on staff that what we throw away has a value beyond its current life.

In order to maintain progress and stop staff slipping back into old behaviours, we now collect data from our cleaning team for each floor so that we can target individual departments.

Resource Footprint

We develop plans based on two key factors – impact as well as visibility. This means that even, though some issues are not significant in terms of reducing our overall footprint, they are perceived to be important to employees and so need to be addressed.

One example was concern among staff over our use of hundreds of thousands of paper cups for water. As a result, these have now been replaced by china mugs. To align this sort of sustainable action with the business, the new mugs where branded with the "3 Little Pigs" as part of our Whole Picture brand campaign. This will save more than £10,000 and 472,000 paper cups a year, equivalent to 1.5% of our overall waste.

We have also improved our photocopier paper by moving to a 100% recycled product. However, paper consumption for our printer paper rose by nearly a third in the last financial year. Further research is required understand why this is happening and identify ways to reduce it.

New York

In 2011 December, a new office was set up in New York for about 45 staff. The refurbishment was carried out by local contractors, and where possible we have mirrored the same working practices as our London office for recycling, lighting and energy usage. The office is in a multi-tenanted building and we share ideas on best practice with the landlords.

While digital is becoming an increasing proportion of Guardian News & Media's (GNM) business, our use of newsprint continues to have a significant environmental impact.

One of the central aims of the paper purchaser over the past few years has been to raise the percentage of newsprint and magazine paper coming from sustainable sources either recycled or certified (ie FSC or PEFC) virgin fibre.

The last financial year saw another step forward, with sustainably sourced paper for GNM newsprint rising to 98% from 96% last year, while magazine paper rose from 87% to 94%.

When purchasing paper, we aim to balance price, quality, security of delivery, carbon emissions and sustainable paper sourcing. This means taking buying decisions that optimise the mix of sustainability characteristics for each paper grade. Individual purchasing decisions will, from time to time, involve trade-offs where an improvement in one area can be achieved only at the expense of another.

In the last financial year we increased the proportion of paper purchased from a British mill that produced excellent recycled product, at lower cost and reduced distribution miles, but the trade-off was lower energy efficiency.

While this decision increased overall carbon emissions, we maintained our paper emission target of 370kg per tonne and recycling target of 80%.

Reduced sales and pagination, as well as a lower weight of paper, meant that GNM saw a 13% reduction in newsprint and magazine paper consumption in 2011-12 to 56,210 tonnes. However, we have maintained our commitment to the sustainable paper policy and indicators, and this is how we performed in the financial year 2011-12:

Use of recycled paper

We met our recycled newsprint target of a minimum of 80%, although the figure fell slightly from 86% to 82%. This fall was due to a greater proportion of GNM's newsprint coming from certified virgin paper in Norway.

Use of virgin paper from certified source

The overall level of certified virgin fibre rose to 92% for GNM products against 82% the previous financial year. This was a result of switching from some North American to Scandinavian mills that use more certified virgin fibre and also have a lower carbon intensity. The certified virgin fibre target is 90% by the end of 2013.

Kilograms of carbon per tonne of paper

While one of the indicators in our paper purchasing policy is to reduce the carbon intensity of the paper we purchase, a decision to shift some purchasing to the Palm recycled paper mill located in the UK, resulted in our paper-related carbon emissions rising by 1260tCO2e or 7% in 2011-12 compared with the previous year. Nevertheless, we continued to meet our target of maintaining emissions below 370kgCO2e per tonne of paper purchased.

The energy use of the Palm mill is one of the highest across our supply base, even though it is one of the newest mills in Europe. It does, however, make high-quality newsprint.

We have been raising the issue of the high power consumption and associated CO2 emissions with the supplier and asking for future projections.

Palm has responded by saying it is planning to change to a more renewable energy supply. We have been advised that it will be purchasing steam from an incinerator plant in the near future, which will reduce the grid electricity purchased.

Chain of custody

We also achieved PEFC certification for paper supplies for Guardian Weekend and the Observer magazines. Details of certification can be found at PEFC.

This means we have a paper trail and a management system in place that tracks the fibre supplies for the paper from sustainably managed forests through to the printed product. To ensure you, the reader, know that the magazines contain only certified virgin material, Guardian Weekend and the Observer magazine carry the PEFC logo.

Reducing paper resource and cost

While not a specific policy KPI, but given that newsprint accounts for a large part of GNM's overall costs, the company decided to further reduce the grammage of the magazine paper for Guardian Weekend (65gsm to 60gsm, November 2011) and Observer Magazine (60gsm to 56gsm, October 2011). This has achieved a reduction of 7% in the tonnage of paper purchased. 

The paper policy

GNM continues to set and assess our paper-purchasing policy, KPIs and performance through the paper purchasing committee. The committee continued to meet during the year to track our procedures against legislation and policy developments.

This included the forthcoming EU Illegal Timber Regulation, which will come into force in March 2013 and the WRI and WBCSD update to Sustainable Procurement of Wood and Paper-based Products (July 2011).

As a result, we have decided to take action to strengthen information from suppliers about uncertified virgin fibre and non-fibre additives or fillers, such as clay and minerals. We will also take steps to investigate the water footprint of our paper supplies.

We will shortly publish an updated paper policy and new KPIs to run up to 2015, focusing on the areas of:

  • The sustainability of the fibre that comprises the main ingredient of paper
  • The consumption of energy and emissions of greenhouse gases
  • The conservation of water resources
  • Pollution control
  • The sustainability of other paper additives

A copy of the current GMG/GNM paper-purchasing policy is available here.

At the heart of our operations are our two fully-operated Guardian print centres (GPCs) in Manchester and Stratford, east London, which print the Guardian and Observer newspapers and undertake some third-party contract printing. All our magazines are printed by our contractor, Polestar.

Both GPC sites have been engaged in our corporate sustainability drive for many years, and further improvements now are all about efficiency gains and maximising revenues through effective management systems.

As a result of a systematic approach to monitoring, planning, testing and implementation, both GPCs in the past financial year ending March 2012, improved energy, water and waste efficiency

Carbon Footprint

Total emissions fell by 9% or 536tCO2e across the print sites, which follows a 10% reduction the previous year. The combined emissions, for both sites, per tonne of newsprint used fell to 116kgCO2 equivalent in 2011-12 compared with 122kgCO2 equivalent.
Continuing falls in newspaper circulation means it is becoming harder to reduce emissions because of fixed energy requirements such as lighting, heating and water treatment.

The print sites have, therefore, done an outstanding job to achieve a year-on-year base load emissions reduction across across both GPCs. Base load is the consumption of electricity that occurs regardless of how or what we print. Therefore, it is a true reflection of improvement that removes the effect of differences in print runs. For example, you can simply improve efficiency by just printing more on a run.

We are looking to develop better metrics to measure efficiency and this is likely to include per page emissions as well as the energy base load.

Our contract printer, Polestar, has also made strong progress, reducing the carbon associated with our magazines, including Guardian Weekend, The Guide, Observer Magazine and Observer Food Monthly by 7% or 178tCO2.

We have continued to monitor our distribution carbon footprint, which includes distribution from our GPC and Polestar print sites to our wholesalers. What we don't yet include are the emissions associated with distributing from wholesaler to retailer.

Carbon per mile travelled has remained very constant, although there was a very small decrease in the amount of carbon dioxide per mile compared with the previous year (from 0.875 to 0.863 kg/mile).

However, we have seen a 3.29% increase in mileage within the distribution contract. This has driven carbon emissions up by 2%.

We are looking at alternative measures that more closely reflect our environmental impact and will develop KPIs with our new distribution partners when the contracts change and we engage our new suppliers in 2012.

As these new arrangements kick in, we will also be sharing distribution with other newspaper titles where possible, and this will help reduce our carbon footprint.

Smart metering and building management system:

Manchester and London GPCs installed smart metering for both electricity and water, and work has continued to closely control the air that is re-circulated within the building, which negates the need to reheat or cool the air from fresh. Proposals are also being drawn up to optimise heating at the print sites.

Lighting improvements at GPC London:

During the current financial year, we will be rolling out a new lighting plan for the production areas, which involves all lights dimming to 10% power when the area is unoccupied.

This system will lead to significant savings given both print sites are industrial in scale and run 24 hours a day. The initial outlay will be recouped within two years, showing a significant saving after that, and there is likely to be a carbon reduction of about 500 tonnes a year.

LED lights are also being tested in the despatch yard, which could replace the existing flood lights.

Resource Footprint

The GPCs reduced water usage by 15.8%, or 1,536,000 litres, across both sites in the last financial year. This is equivalent to the daily water use of 12,000 average UK citizens and follows a reduction of 14% in 2010-11.

Our Manchester print site, in particular, made great strides by reducing its need for water by 32%, or 1,218,000 litres. This was mainly due to improved controls, water recycling, cleaning processes and observation of water use to detect and fix leaks.

Ink consumption across both presses has also reduced this year by 14%, or 169,905kg. This reduction was due to efficiency measures and reduced printing. For example, in Manchester, grams of black ink per page fell from 0.0268g to 0.0250g or 7%.

Water reduction initiatives:

Sensors were placed in all urinals and two changes were made to ink and damp levels on the press at the Manchester site. Unfortunately, we have no specific data on how much the first improvement saved, but the second adjustment resulted in a 4.5% reduction of water usage on the press.

Waste Footprint

With a focus on segregation and better resource management, total waste at the print sites fell by 13% or 191,980kgs. London achieved a 17% reduction in total waste, while both print sites saw improvement in recycling by 4% (Manchester now 84% and London 78%). Both sites also reduced hazardous waste, which includes solvents, plate developers and oil filters.

Paper waste continues to be a focal point, given that it is a valuable resource, and recycling it, therefore, generates an income.

Waste reductions and recycling Initiatives:

Both print sites are looking for opportunities to reduce resource use in the print process as well as ensuring that currently unavoidable waste is segregated and recycled.

It is not only paper that is valuable but also chemicals and aluminium print plates, given the sharp rise in world commodity prices. Further benefits are seen in general waste reductions due to an increase in separation, witnessed by a 55% (Manchester) and 19% (London) drop in general waste to landfill in the past 12 months.

A few years ago, Guardian News and Media (GNM) set an ambitious challenge to be carbon positive.

Carbon positive, for operations, means achieving best practice in reducing our direct and indirect environmental impacts and supporting social justice within the boundaries we can control or influence.

Of course, carbon is only one of the issues we face in our operations. That is why we also concentrate on other key impacts such as resource consumption including water and paper as well as waste creation from across the business.

GNM is planning to transform into a digital first company, which means that our impacts from traditional newspaper production will diminish over time while our digital environmental impacts will grow.

In recognition of the importance of this, a board level sponsor, Tanya Cordrey, director of digital development, has been appointed to establish a leadership position in digital sustainability.

We continue to commit to supporting research in this area through a number of collaborations that aim to make a genuine contribution to knowledge in this field.

This year for the first time we include the carbon footprint of our digital operations in this report, based on the work by the Sympact project. We believe we are also the first media companies to estimate our annual carbon footprint for the delivery of our website based on all users.
 
This has been challenging, but we are pleased to be able to present an estimated carbon footprint of www.theguardian.com for the year 2011-12 to be in the magnitude of 10,000 tonnes CO2 equivalent – about a third of our current GNM footprint.

We have tried to provide a simple overview of the methodology. However, if you would like to see the details of the model, they will be made available in a forthcoming peer-reviewed academic paper produced by Sympact and through our sustainability blog.

Quality data collection and measurement is vital in this area of the business if we are to continue to improve our performance, which is why we have a section dedicated to this (Footprints). The operational activities we cover within this section of the report include:

  • Office operations
  • Digital operations
  • Print operations
  • Paper purchasing
  • Procurement

The financial year ending March 2012 proved predominantly positive in managing and reducing the negative elements of our environmental footprint. We lowered carbon emissions at sources where we have direct control (including offices, data centres, print sites and business travel) by 3%, saved 16% in water usage at the print sites, improved office recycling rates to 78%, lowered print waste by 13% and made advances in our sustainable paper sourcing.

When purchasing paper we aim to balance price, quality, security of delivery, carbon emissions and sustainable paper sourcing. GNM refers to sustainable paper sourcing as paper fibre that is from a recycled or certified (ie FSC or PEFC) source.

This means taking buying decisions that optimise the mix of sustainability characteristics for each paper grade. Individual purchasing decisions will, from time to time, involve trade-offs where an improvement in one area can be achieved only at the expense of another.

In the past financial year, we have purchased more recycled paper from a new British mill. This decision increased overall carbon emissions, but we maintained our paper emission target of 370kg per tonne.

In the same period, 98% of the newsprint and 94% of magazine-grade paper used for the Guardian and Observer was either recycled or used certified virgin fibre.

Our total carbon footprint increased by 2% to 32,850tCO2e over the same period as a result of these paper-purchasing decisions and increased business travel.

While sustainability audits report year-on-year changes, it is also important to consider the long-term performance of GNM. In fact, carbon emissions have fallen since our base year of 2009-10 by 25%.

We have been collecting data on our directly controlled emissions (offices, print sites and business travel) for longer and these have reduced by 31% since our base line of 2008-09.

This improvement is predominately the result of improved management, new efficient buildings, reduced pagination, smarter procurement and digital and print process optimisation across the business.

Like any ambitious project, there have also been areas where we have struggled. Business travel emissions rose by 42% or 320tCO2e in the past financial year. Air travel rose by 52% or 240tCO2e and train travel by 32%. This is the second year to see an increase in air travel.

We believe the majority of this increase is due to improved data collection, but the development of a strong presence in New York is having an impact. We are planning to work with our travel management company (see procurement section) to identify innovative ways to address this.

In order to gauge the perceptions of our staff, we carried out a brief survey in June 2012, and 377 people responded out of a total of about 1,600. While 67% of respondents said they believed GNM has effective environmental practices in place, only 47% felt that GNM encourages them to take an active part reducing their environmental impact at work.

To redress this, we recognise the need to ensure that actions we take in the field of sustainability also contribute to the core purpose of GNM. This will help ensure that senior and middle management support the desire of employees to make a difference.

Secondly, we recognise we need constantly to work at improving communication, by letting staff know what actions we are taking and demonstrating the impacts they have. For example, we launched a Love Your Waste recycling campaign, which was initially successful but tailed off towards the end of the year as we did not effectively communicate progress.

Because our largest impacts arise outside our direct control, we continue to identify and address sustainability through our procurement. Particular attention is paid to managing and reporting on the sustainability credentials of our key suppliers in the digital field.

To further support our knowledge of sustainable procurement across the business, a number of workshops were held for staff. Working with the internal procurement team to look at how sustainable thinking could identify broader and more complex risks and opportunities that may influence or affect the business.

While there is a growing emphasis at GNM on becoming a "digital first" company, our newspapers continue to play an important role, and we have made marked progress in limiting the environmental impacts of both our print sites and paper purchasing.

Print site sustainability is all about efficiency gains, and our Manchester and Stratford plants have seen reductions in energy, natural resources and hazardous material through a systematic approach to monitoring, planning, testing and implementation.

Digital products (ie websites and apps) are typically viewed as being "carbon light" or low-impact, and, as a result, there has been little pressure for suppliers or businesses to be accountable for the emissions or environmental impacts.

This is in particularly stark contrast to the expectations of paper sourcing and manufacture of the public, NGOs and the sector itself.

Delivering our digital products requires energy and produces carbon dioxide emissions, so it is important for us to understand more about what drives this demand for energy and what we can do about it.

This is in addition to the depletion of natural resources, pollution and associated ecological impacts that result from demand for the physical equipment and the sources of energy generation through out the life cycle.

We have been working to create a digital sustainability strategy, which aims to minimise our digital footprint while also maximising accessibility and the quality of our readers' experience, improving operational resilience and supporting commercial growth.

Guardian News and Media (GNM) recognises that there is currently very little detailed research into digital media environmental impacts. It is also not clear where the boundaries of responsibility lie. Is it the computer hardware makers, the networks, the Guardian or the consumer who logs on to our website?

This is largely due to the complexity of how digital systems and the internet works and interconnects. To rectify this GNM has been developing its own research in partnership with Bristol and Surrey universities.

We teamed up with Bristol-based Sympact to focus on developing a deeper understanding of the energy use and carbon dioxide emissions that result from the delivery of our digital products, such as theguardian.com.

As a result, this year we have published an estimated carbon footprint of the guardian website for the financial year 2010-11 in a separate digital footprint section of the report.

We have also been working with Stephen Wood, an engineering doctorate student at the University of Surrey, who is researching whether it is possible to reduce environmental impacts at the design stage of the software product development, in addition to improving operational efficiency of data centres and the hardware. This may take the form of curating content on the website to improve navigation and user experience.

Sympact and Wood have been collaborating as well as working with Guardian staff to better understand what digital sustainability means for GNM. This integrated approach is key because the knowledge gained by the Sympact project is essential to assessing the potential impact of software design interventions and GNM's digital teams provide us with an understanding of which interventions are practically possible. 

In recognition of the importance of this issue, a board-level sponsor, Tanya Cordrey, director of digital development, has been appointed to establish a leadership position in digital sustainability.

The immediate task for GNM as the sponsor is to ensure that outstanding data and information are collected to strengthen and complete the research. Subsequent responsibilities will be to oversee the transformation of the research into practical action and the implementation of a digital sustainability strategy in support of GNM's overall sustainability and digital first vision.

Of course, in the digital field not everything is under our direct control so we have also been assessing our impacts through the supply chain.

Clearly, one of the biggest impacts is our reliance on a global network of data centres for delivering digital services. Not only do we need to understand how to reduce our impacts in this area, we also need to think about the implications of increased digital energy demands and how resilient the digital first model is to the possibility of energy blackouts.

The business also needs to be aware of future operational costs, legislative requirements, and reputational risks.

Why act?

The Guardian is driven to address and reduce the environmental impacts of digital media delivery as part of its carbon positive commitment to take climate change more seriously.

The digital sustainability strategy also gives us the opportunity to engage with our audience, showcase our openness and demonstrate how we are contributing to a more sustainable future.

On top of this, we hope to improve the design of our digital products, cut costs and reduce our carbon footprint across the value chain.

We also recognise the risks from inaction, including opening ourselves to criticism that we are not living our values and failing to spot and address strategic risks such as energy security.

Key areas of attention

Influencing behavioural change
Many leading companies, such as 02 and Proctor & Gamble, recognise the largest carbon impacts lie not in their direct operations but from the customers' use of their products and services.

As a result, they have been developing strategies to encourage their customers to change their behaviour. That is sometimes through the development of new products – such as washing powder that allow customers to reduce the water temperature (Ariel 30) – as well as through providing information and education.

GNM's sustainability vision already has a commitment to "act as an agent of change for good through inspiring readers, customers and staff to change behaviours".

While our main concentration has been achieving this through our editorial content, we recognise the opportunity to improve our readers' understanding of their digital environmental footprint.

One way of doing that is to develop interactive tools and personal internet energy monitors. One app created by our university partners was tested at the Guardian's Open Weekend.

Other opportunities lie in encouraging readers to view our content on low-power devices, such as Kindle, iPad and smartphones.

We can also encourage good power management practice on PCs and Macs, as well as recommending that home wi-fi networks are turned off overnight.

Operational efficiency
Perhaps the most obvious action we can take is to reduce our carbon footprint by reducing the energy of the hardware in the data centres we use – whether owned by us in our own buildings and third party locations, or even equipment owned by cloud service providers, such as Google or Akamide.

This could be through using less kit by virtualising physical servers or storage and using only what we actually need when we need it. Another way will be to buy equipment with greater energy efficiency and also evaluate the energy sources of the data centres.

We also plan to undertake a sustainability risk assessment of our supply chain and produce a supplier code of conduct policy. This will allow us to apply due diligence to ensure sustainability principles are addressed in contracts to minimise risks to GNM.

For more details of the challenges we face with our digital supply chain please see the procurement section.

Product development
There is a need to build further engagement with the internal digital teams. One idea is to run a Hack Day or some form of interactive workshop to see how we can create a framework or language for building digital sustainability thinking in mainstream software development.

It will also be important to engage with product teams about developing sustainability principles in design.

This work will hopefully help to inform decisions in the product process, including design, development and maintenance.

Actions taken to reduce operational impact 2011-12

Digital systems architecture
The Guardian's digital systems team runs a large data centre to serve our global audience. It uses a significant amount of power to both run and cool it, and we are committed to reducing this where possible both from an emissions and a cost perspective.

In the financial year 2011-12, we have looked extensively at using cloud processing where possible to take advantage of available scale (size) and efficiency. This will allow us to access more server processing power when we hit peak traffic demand rather than buy new kit that will be under-utilised.

A good example of this is the way we are serving traffic to our highly successful Facebook application. Were we to do that from our data centres, we would have had to considerably increase the number of servers to cope with the rise in traffic. Instead, our Facebook application is hosted entirely in the cloud, where capacity is allocated on demand. We believe that this has saved power, emissions and costs.

A large proportion of our data centre equipment is now reaching the end of its life. By focusing on power consumption we have chosen suitable units with the lowest power needs and high energy efficiency.

The shift to using cloud computing and the delivery of the new infrastructure are key objectives for the financial year 2012-13. These we believe will both lead to lower emissions and power costs while allowing us to keep pace with our digital ambitions at an affordable cost.

Office IT hardware procurement
It's not only our online presence where we can make a difference; we also use a lot of IT equipment for our 1,600 staff, for example – desktop computers, printers, phones and office servers.

Over the past financial year, we were able to reduce our energy use by further virtualising our servers. We're replacing about 58 of our servers with an equivalent platform of 20. This will reduce energy usage from 58kW to 20kW per hour, leading to savings of more than 300MWh per year or £55,000, equivalent to 156 tonnes of CO2e.

Other proposed plans are to reduce storage, given the proposed systems incorporate the latest innovations in power efficiency. This will decrease the server count, which should lead to savings of more than 460MWh per year, equivalent to 239 tonnes of CO2e.

In this report, we are able for the first time to show the carbon footprint of our digital media operations. Guardian News and Media (GNM) has developed the methodology in partnership with the Sympact Project, researchers at the University of Bristol and Surrey.

The estimated carbon footprint of providing content for www.guardian.co.uk and www.guardiannews.com, as well as for our audience to consume it, for the year 2011-12 is about 10,000 tonnes CO2e – around a third of our current overall business footprint.

Why

There is a perception that digital products (ie, websites, blogs and mobile apps) are typically viewed as being "carbon light" or low impact, especially compared with paper products.

This is largely because people do not understand the complexity of the internet, given its global and opaque nature, and do not have a direct connection to the effects of their media consumption.

We teamed up with Sympact to focus on developing a deeper understanding of the energy use and carbon dioxide emissions that result from the delivery of our digital products, such as guardian.co.uk. Sympact is joint-funded by the Research Councils UK Digital Economy and Energy Programmes.

We are not doing this as a result of regulatory pressure, but to better understand the situation for ourselves and share our findings and approach with others in the industry to help stimulate debate and encourage the development of more sustainable digital products and services.

How it works

To build our stakeholders' understand it may be valuable to set out what happens when a webpage is accessed.

As you use your laptop, tablet or smart phone, requests are sent from your device to a number of different server computers that build the components of the page, ie the template, text, pictures, video and adverts.

These requests are transferred through your Wi-Fi modem or the 3G network via your internet service provider into the internet infrastructure or network and out to the server computers, which return the data.

As set out in figure below, the path your request takes depends on which device you use, as this determines the access-network route into the internet infrastructure. The path through the internet network is driven by which server computers need to be accessed to provide data, which in turn is controlled by the type of request (ie video or text) and your geographical location.

So, in the case of the Guardian webpage, the template and text comes from our own data centre in London. But many of the other elements, such as images, video, audio, and advertising are often stored on third-party servers (such as content delivery networks) that are physically closer to the reader around the world.

The Findings

Based on this analysis, we can provide an estimate of the global energy footprint of reading the Guardian online. The estimated carbon footprint for the year 2011-12 from our web operations is in the magnitude of 10,000 tonnes of CO2e. As an absolute value, this figure should be used with caution as there remain considerable uncertainties due to some of the estimates and assumptions that we have had to make.

But our primary goal for doing this work was not to report for the sake of it but to learn more about where emissions occur in this system – to guide us in knowing where we should concentrate our efforts in the future. As such, the findings have been revealing if not straightforward in the conclusions that we should draw.

More details on the methodology of the model and complexities we faced will be published shortly on our sustainability blog.

Energy consumed using guardian online is heavily dependent on the equipment (customer device) being used because, at about 86%, this is the largest source of emissions of our footprint. This makes controlling our emissions difficult. Indeed, the server computers, where we have most control, represent a much smaller element of the emissions.

Among the most significant variables are the time that users spend consuming content, the device they use to do so, and the technology they use to connect to the internet.

For example, in the table below we compare three examples of browsing guardian online for 11 minutes (a typical visit). The first, using a laptop connected to the internet over Wi-Fi; the second via a smartphone connected over a 3G mobile network; and the third a tablet via Wi-Fi. As might be expected, the smartphone system uses less energy overall. Although the tablet still uses only half the energy of the laptop.

But each of these scenarios would suggest that we should be prioritising very different activities if we wish to reduce the overall impact of our websites on the environment. In the laptop scenario, where user devices dominate the energy footprint, we might best focus on raising awareness through our editorial coverage.

In a world where mobile access dominates, the networks and servers become more significant, suggesting we should be striving first to reduce the energy used by these components. Reducing the volume of data required to meet users' needs for news access would be one way of perhaps addressing this issue. This was discussed in more detail in previous blog post.

Actions

Of course, analysing data is one thing, but far more important is what we then do with it. The key recommendations for making progress on reducing our digital emissions are:

  • Influencing behavioural change To lead the way on behaviour change through transparency and education
  • Operational efficiency To reduce carbon footprint and costs by rationalising data centres through virtualisation and optimisation, and meet industry best practice
  • Product development Design for sustainability to optimise delivery of content and user experience
For more information visit the Digital section of operations.

Should the police now formally investigate allegations of rape and sexual abuse against Sir Jimmy Savile?

After a woman reported a "historic" rape allegation on Monday, Scotland Yard said her claim would be "reviewed and assessed". However, no decision had been taken on whether to open a formal investigation.

Also on Monday, Surrey police confirmed that they had interviewed Savile under caution in 2007 about sexual assault allegations dating back to the 1970s. No charges were brought after the Crown Prosecution Service advised that there was insufficient evidence to bring a case to court.

That should not come as much of a surprise. Allegations of rape or sexual assault are difficult enough to prove at the best of times, with often little or no corroboration. Savile's alleged victims would have had to satisfy a court that they had a clear recollection of events around 30 years ago. They would also have to explain why they had waited until the former television presenter was in his eighties before coming forward.

Since then, of course, a number of other alleged victims have given interviews to journalists working on television documentaries. If the police had known about these allegations in 2007, that might have strengthened the case against Savile. But the women who came forward after Savile's death last year are unlikely to have known in 2007 that he was under investigation.

Scotland Yard is now facing something of a dilemma. It is too late for Savile to be prosecuted. The police would be accused of wasting scarce resources if they conducted detailed investigations into allegations against a defendant who is no longer able to stand trial.

On the other hand, people want to know whether these allegations can be substantiated. The police would be performing a valuable public service by collecting the available evidence.

In my view, the police need to investigate whether there is evidence against anyone else who might be charged in connection with these allegations. To some extent, that requires detectives to make inquiries into the claims against Savile himself. But that is as far as it should go.

And who might those other defendants be? There is no suggestion that Savile had an accomplice. Some newspapers have pointed the finger at the BBC, both for failing to investigate allegations of abuse by a BBC presenter that may have taken place on BBC premises and for not broadcasting evidence of abuse obtained last year by Newsnight. Perhaps a declaration of interest is needed here: I was on the staff of the BBC for 25 years and still work for the corporation as a freelancer.

The editor of Newsnight has said his team had no new evidence that would have helped the police. He knew the CPS had decided there was insufficient evidence for a prosecution. Whether you think that this was the right editorial decision rather depends on whether you think Newsnight should broadcast a celebrity exposé of an individual who could no longer defend himself. There seem to be no issues of law here.

The next question is whether the BBC was criminally liable for allowing abuse to take place on its premises. Might the BBC have been at fault for permitting vulnerable guests to visit presenters in dressing rooms at Television Centre? Could it be liable as a co-conspirator or even for what used to be called incitement and is now described as intentionally encouraging or assisting the commission of an offence?

Surely not. Imagine the outcry if Auntie had insisted on a chaperone. That would surely have been unsustainable. In general, an omission to act is not in itself a criminal offence. Nor is failing to prevent or report criminal conduct.

There are exceptions, of course: parents are required to care for their children. Organisations that allow public access must ensure people's safety. Employers have duties to their staff. Gross failures in these cases may lead to criminal liability. But I cannot see how the BBC or any of its staff could be prosecuted for failing to stop a presenter from committing offences of this sort on its premises. As far as we know, nobody complained.

Should the BBC have continued to use Savile? Here, the corporation may be on shakier ground. He was not on the staff, of course, but he must have signed countless BBC contracts. The current version of the BBC's standard contract requires presenters to not undermine the BBC's reputation for integrity and decency. The BBC could have sacked him or, at the very least, stopped putting him on the air.

No doubt BBC managers told themselves that it would have been wrong to have dropped a popular presenter because of unsubstantiated allegations about his private life.
